metadata.title: Application of Pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 Nano-clusters as Superior Me- dia for Acetylene and Ethylene Adsorption: DFT Calculations

Application of Pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 Nano-clusters as Superior Media for Acetylene and Ethylene Adsorption: DFT Calculations

Application of Pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 Nano-clusters as Superior
Media for Acetylene and Ethylene Adsorption: DFT Calculations
Ali Shokuhi Rad *a , Sadegh Mehdi Aghaei b , Vahid Poralijan a , Majid Peyravi c , Mahmoud Mirzaei d
a Department of Chemical Engineering, Qaemshahr Branch, Islamic Azad University, Qaemshahr, Iran
b Quantum Electronic Structures Technology Lab, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Florida
International University, Miami, Florida 33174, United States
c Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran
d Bioinformatics Research Center, School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Isfahan University of
Medical Sciences, Isfahan, Iran
*E-mail: a.shokuhi@gmail.com , a.shokuhi@qaemiau.ac.ir
Tel: 0098-9112134588
Fax: 0098-11132367735
ABSTRACT
In this study, density functional theory (DFT) method with B3LYP-D and MPW1PW91
functionals is carried out to explicate the adsorption properties of small unsaturated
hydrocarbons (acetylene and ethylene molecules) on the surfaces of pristine and Ni-decorated
B12P12 nano-clusters. More specifically, binding energies, natural bond orbital (NBO) charge transfer, dipole moment, frontier molecular orbitals, density of states (DOS), and global indices
of activities are analyzed to deeply perceive the fluctuations of electronic and chemical
properties of pure and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage upon acetylene and ethylene adsorption. Our theoretical findings indicate that Ni atom can be adsorbed on the surface of B12P12 nanocage in three distinct configurations (P1, P2, and P3), where P1 is found as the most stable
geometry. Although the acetylene (ethylene) molecule is weakly physisorbed on the surface of pristine B12P12 nano-cage with adsorption energy of −34.1 (−30.7) kJmole -1 , a significant improvement in their adsorption energies is found by utilizing Ni-decorated B12P12 as the adsorbent. The highest adsorption energy for acetylene (ethylene) adsorption on Ni-decorated B12P12 is −270.6 (−232.0) kJmole -1 in P2 (P3) geometry, suggesting that Ni decoration of B12P12 nano-cage enhances its capability toward acetylene and ethylene adsorption. It is also discovered
the band gap of pristine B12P12 nano-cage decreases after complexation with Ni atom, and increases again upon adsorption of acetylene and ethylene molecules on its surface. In addition,
the values of softness and electrophilicity for Ni-decorated B12P12 are higher than other structures. Our results suggest that Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-clusters show promise in acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption.
Keywords: Nanocluster, Density functional theory, metal decoration, Gas adsorption

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The catalytic reactions mostly happen on the surfaces, ergo a detailed knowledge of surface
reactions is a prerequisite to find the most efficient catalysts, the understating of which is
essential to simplify the design of catalysts for other important reactions. The adsorption of
unsaturated hydrocarbon molecules, such as acetylene (C2H2) and ethylene (C2H4), on transition metals (TM) is of great importance due to their key role in elementary catalytic reactions [1-5].
There have been quite a number of theoretical and experimental studies on adsorption of
acetylene and ethylene on different TMs, for instance, Cu, Ni, Pd, Pt, Rd, and Ag nanoparticles
in the literature [1-13]. The ethylene adsorption on TM surfaces can happen in two distinct
configurations: a  bonding which involves one metal atom on the surface or di--bonding that
includes two metal atoms on the surface [7]. Nonetheless, the adsorption of acetylene on TM
surfaces is more tangled than that of ethylene. Marinova et al. found that three-fold hollow and
the diagonal four-fold hollow are the most stable adsorption configurations for adsorption of
acetylene on Cu surface [10]. Medlin et al. also discovered that the most stable geometry for
acetylene adsorption on Pd, Pt, and Rh surfaces is three-fold parallel-bridge and on Ni surface is
-bridge configuration [12]. TM clusters have also garnered great attention due to their pivotal
role in development of catalysis nanotechnology and data storage devices [14-29]. The physical
and chemical properties of metal based nano-clusters depend critically on their size and
structures. Several experimental and theoretical studies of acetylene and ethylene’s adsorption on
TM clusters have been already reported [14-17,20,21,28].
Recently, several researchers studied different metal and non-metal included nanostructures in
order to improve their sensing capabilities toward various analytes. [29-34]. Lu et al. have
employed Pd-modified carbon nanotubes (CNT) for high ethylene selectivity [29]. Saha et al.
found that doping of fullerene C60 by Pd or Ru atom gives rise to an enhancement in the
hydrogen uptakes [30]. We reported that modification of graphene sheet by Al atom provides a
superior media toward CO, CO2, NO, NO2 and H2O adsorption [31,32]. In addition, we investigated pristine, N- and B-doped silicene nanoribbons [35,36] and introduced them as
suitable sensors for CO, NH3, and H2S detection [34].
Inspired by successes in the development of CNT and fullerene C60, different heteroatomic
tubular or spherical fullerene-like structures based on non-carbon inorganic materials have
aroused a great deal of interest [37-50]. Strout et al. revealed that the fullerene-like nano-cages
X12Y12 are the most stable structures among all (XY)n (X = B, Al, Ga,… and Y = N, P, As, …) semiconductors [37]. Al12N12, Al12P12, B12N12, and B12P12 are of great importance owing to their high stability, large energy band gap, and excellent chemical and physical properties. BN nano-
cages were synthesized by Oku et al. in 2004 [38], and detected by laser desorption time-of-
flight mass spectrometry. These semiconductors have potential to be engaged as adsorbent for
various analytes [39-50]. In our recent works [39-41], the adsorption behavior of guanine,
pyrrole, and Furan molecules on above-mentioned nano-cages are studied using density
functional theory (DFT) calculations. It was found that although Al12N12 has the highest adsorption energy, more alterations in electronic properties of B-containing nano-cages are
observed upon adsorption of the aforementioned molecules. In addition, the adsorption
properties of phenol on the surfaces of different nano-cages were examined by Soltani et al. [42].
Beheshtian et al. also explored geometries, stabilities, and electronic properties of CO and NO
adsorbed AlN nano-cages [43]. In another study, Wang et al. introduced AlN nanostructures as
hydrogen storage materials [44].
The Ni adsorption on the surface of Al12P12 and Al12N12, and B12N12 were also considered [45-47]. It was revealed that the Ni atom is adsorbed on aforementioned nano-cages in distinct
geometries. We also found that Ni-decorated nano-cages have higher tendency for H2 adsorption compared to the bare nano-cages [47,48]. Besides, the hydrogen storage capability of Ni-
decorated Al12N12 was studied by Zhang et al. [49]. They discovered that Ni atom of Ni-Al12N12 nano-cage is able to adsorb up to three hydrogen molecules, while in the bare Al12N12 nano-cage, each Al atom adsorbs one hydrogen molecule.
To the best of our knowledge, no study to this point has explored the unsaturated hydrocarbon
molecule’s adsorption on the nano-cages. In this paper, we employ DFT method to investigate
the adsorption of acetylene and ethylene molecules on pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 nanocluster. First, the impact of Ni decoration of B12P12 on geometry and electronic properties of B12P12 nano-cage is studied. Three distinct geometries are found for decoration of Ni on the nano-cage. Next, the acetylene and ethylene adsorption ability of Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage is compared with pristine nano-cage. The obtained results are analyzed by considering binding
energies, the natural bond orbital (NBO) charge transfer, dipole moment, frontier molecular
orbitals, density of states (DOS), and global indices of activities.

sections.heading: 2. COMPUTATION DETAILS
sections.text:
To follow the geometries of adsorbed acetylene and ethylene on pristine and Ni-decorated
B12P12, DFT method using B3LYP-D (D is for dispersion forces) with 6-31G (d,p) basis set which is implemented in Gaussian 09 suite of program has been used [51]. It has been formerly
proven that B3LYP-D/6-31G(d,p) is an optimal level of theory to achieve reliable and accurate
results at minimum cost [52]. Furthermore, the functional of MPW1PW91 (which uses Perdew-
Wang exchange as modified by Adamo and Barone combined with PW91 [53]) was employed to
consider van der Waals (vdW) interactions. It has been demonstrated that the hybrid
MPW1PW91 functional is a reliable method for nanostructure systems [54].
The net charge transfer upon complexation of acetylene and ethylene molecules with pristine
and decorated B12P12 was calculated using natural bond orbital (NBO) from the differences in their charge concentrations before and after adsorption. Binding energies are calculated
according to the following equations:

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
3.1.Optimized geometries and interaction energies
The adsorption behavior of acetylene (A) and ethylene (E) molecules on the surface of bare
and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage are scrutinized. The stability, geometry and electronic properties of pure B12P12 are recently reported by Beheshtian et al. [50], finding that B12P12 nano-cage is a semiconductor with a band gap of 3.80 eV. To begin with, the adsorption of
acetylene and ethylene molecules on pure B12P12 nano-cage is studied at B3LYP-D/6-31G (d,p) level of theory. Fig. 1 presents the top and side views of optimized structures of adsorbed
molecules on the surface of B12P12 nano-cage. The adsorption energies of acetylene and ethylene molecules on pristine B12P12 nano-cage are −34.1 and −30.7 kJ/mole, respectively, indicating that the interactions between these molecules and B12P12 are very weak (See Table 1). As can be seen, the molecules aligned parallel with respect to the BP nano-cage, and the interaction
distances of nano-cage from acetylene and ethylene molecules are 3.23 and 3.25 Å, respectively
(See Table 1).
hybridization. This finding agrees well with distortion of the acetylene’s geometry upon
adsorption on transition metals [1,2,57,58]. The adsorption energies of acetylene molecule in P1,
P2, and P3 geometries are −234.5, −270.6, and −267.1 kJ/mole, respectively, indicating that the
interaction of acetylene molecule with B12P12 nano-cage is chemisorption (See Table 1). These values for adsorption energies are less than that experimentally and theoretically reported for
acetylene adsorption on Ni (111) (−280.3 kJ/mole) [11,59]. The value achieved for acetylene
adsorption in P2 geometry is 7.9 times greater than that of pristine B12P12, suggesting that Ni decoration increases the capabilities of B12P12 nano-cluster toward acetylene adsorption. The acetylene molecule is positioned at a distance of 1.86, 1.86, and 1.85 Å from Ni atom in P1, P2,
and P3 geometries, respectively (Table 1). The greater stability of acetylene (ethylene)-Ni-B12P12 complex nano-cage compared to the acetylene (ethylene)-B12P12 complex can be attributed to the shorter interaction distances of acetylene molecule and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage. Clearly, the adsorption energy is inversely proportional to the distance of adsorbate and adsorbent.

Quite similar to acetylene adsorption, the adsorption of ethylene molecule on Ni-decorated
B12P12 is highly exothermic. For P1, P2, and P3 geometries, the interaction energies are −200.6, −219.2, and −232.0 kJ/mole, and interaction distances of Ni atom with ethylene molecule are
1.95, 1.95, and 1.94 Å, respectively (See Table 1). These values for adsorption energy are much
greater than that experimentally determined for ethylene adsorption on Ni (110) (−50.30
kJ/mole) [60]. It is clear that adsorption of Ni atom on pristine B12P12 (in P3 geometry) enhances the sensing capability of B12P12 nano-cage toward ethylene adsorption by 7.5 times. The interaction of ethylene molecule with Ni-decorated B12P12 is weaker than acetylene molecule due
to lower adsorption energies and larger interaction distances. The order of stability for acetylene
on Ni-decorated B12P12 system is P2 > P3 > P1, however it is P3 > P2 > P1 for ethylene adsorption on Ni-decorated B12P12 system. These results are inversely comparative to the stability of Ni-decorated B12P12 system where the P1 geometry is found as the most stable geometry. One conceivable reason is that the higher stability of P1 geometry makes the system
less sensitive toward further adsorption.
In order to take into account the vdW interactions, MPW1PW91 as an additional functional is
employed for calculations of binding energies (See Table 1). The binding energy of acetylene
(ethylene) molecule on pristine B12P12 nano-cage increases from −34.1 (−30.7) kJ/mole to −35.5 (−31.4) kJ/mole when considering vdW interactions using MPW1PW91 method. It seems that
vdW interaction has minor effect on adsorption of acetylene and ethylene molecules on pristine
nanocage. The interaction energies obtained by MPW1PW91 functional also increase 9.68%,
11.35%, and 1.61% ( 8.07%, 11.72%, and 2.71%) as compared to those calculated using B3LYP-
D method upon adsorption of acetylene (ethylene) molecule on Ni-decorated B12P12 in P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively. Apparently, for both acetylene and ethylene molecules, the
effect of vdW is more pronounced in P2 rather than P1 and P3 which can be attributed to their
electronic structure.
3.2.Charge transfer and dipole moments
In order to study the impacts of acetylene and ethylene adsorption on the electronic structures
of bare and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage, the net charge transfer on Ni and adsorbates using NBO and dipole moments are calculated, as listed in Table 1. The dipole moment of bare B12P12
nano-cage is basically zero due to the lack of charge separation. Upon adsorption of acetylene
(ethylene) molecule on bare B12P12 nano-cage, very little charge of +0.04 e (+0.05 e) transfers from the adsorbates to nano-cage, disturbing the electron density of the complex. These small
amounts of charge transfer agree well with the low adsorption energies of acetylene and ethylene
molecules on bare B12P12. The values of the dipole moments are 1.68 D for acetylene adsorption and 2.27 D for ethylene adsorption, and their vectors originate from nano-cluster and point
toward the adsorbates. The dipole moments are found to have direct relationship with interaction
distance and inverse relationship with adsorption energies. The B12P12 has higher adsorption energy, smaller charge transfer, and larger interaction distances toward acetylene molecule
adsorption than ethylene molecule. It is worth mentioning that the NBO charges of adsorbed
pyrrole and Furan molecules on B12P12 nano-cage are +0.047 and +0.023 e, respectively [40,41]. Moreover, the value of dipole moment for pyrrole adsorption on BP nano-cage is 2.02 D and for
Furan adsorption on BP nano-cage 1.51 D [40,41]. These results indicate that the components of
aforementioned complexes (acetylene-, ethylene-, Furan-, and pyrrole-B12P12) have a non-ionic nature. The intramolecular bonding between B12P12 and adsorbates can be determined by impacts of covalence and ion-ion interactions.
To compensate the lack of ionic nature of the components, the B12P12 nano-cage can be decorated by a transition metal. It is expected that the decoration of Ni on the B12P12 nano-cage enhances the dipole moment of the bare nano-cage owing to the perturbation in the electron
density at the interface of the Ni and nano-cage. The Ni atom is positively charged whereas the
nano-cluster becomes electron-rich. The vectors of dipole moments in all geometries point
toward the Ni atom, originating from the nano-cage. Upon adsorption of acetylene and ethylene
molecules on Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage, the electron density of the system is disturbed again due to the charge transfer from Ni atom to the molecules. In the case of acetylene
adsorption on Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage, the values of dipole moments are 1.70, 1.69, and 1.93 D for P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively. The charge on Ni atom in acetylene-Ni-
decorated B12P12 complex is positive. The NBO charges for P1, P2, and P3 geometries are +0.480, +0.481, and +0.504 e, respectively. Nevertheless, the acetylene molecule is negatively
charged. The net charge transfers to acetylene (based on NBO) are −0.220, −0.220, and −0.228 e
for P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively. The results for geometries P1 and P2 are found to be
almost similar. In the case of P3 geometry, a higher amount of charge transfer is observed for
both Ni and acetylene compared to P1 and P2 geometries, which is consistent with the larger
dipole moment of P3 geometry with respect to P1 and P2 geometries. On the other hand, for
ethylene adsorption on Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cluster, the values of dipole moments are 3.76, 4.20, and 2.20 D for P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively, which are larger than those of
acetylene adsorption. The NBO charges on Ni atom are 0.632, 0.635, and 0.599 e and the
charges on ethylene molecule are −0.183, −0.166, and −0.249 e for P1, P2, and P3 geometries,
respectively. The change in dipole moment in P1, P2, and P3 geometries is in accordance with
change in NBO charge on Ni atom, whereas it is not consistent with NBO charge on ethylene
molecule. One possible reason is the separation between charges. The intensity of charges is not
the only influential factor in evaluating the dipole moment. Not only does the dipole moment
depend on the charge intensity, but also it can be affected by the displacement of charges.
Furthermore, the direction of dipole moment is toward adsorbates sides.
3.3.Frontier molecular orbitals
In order to get deeper insights about the influence of Ni decoration on the electronic
properties of pristine B12P12 nano-cage, as well as the impact of acetylene and ethylene adsorption on the electronic properties of pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage, the frontier molecular orbitals are explored for their energies and distribution of densities. Table 2
presents the energies of highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied
molecular orbital (LUMO), Fermi level energy (EFL), and band gap (Eg). The distributions of HOMOs and LUMOs are also provided in Fig. 3. The EFL (at T = 0 K) is approximately located at the middle of the HOMO-LUMO energy gap. As reported before [50] and confirmed in this
work, the B12P12 nano-cage is a semiconductor with a band gap of 3.70 eV, while Ni is a metal with a very small band gap of 0.22 eV. The HOMO and LUMO of B12P12 nano-cage have energies of −6.83 and −3.13 eV, respectively. The HOMO is mostly situated on P atoms;
however, the LUMO is uniformly dispersed over all atoms of the nano-cage, as shown in Fig. 3.
Upon adsorption of acetylene (ethylene) molecule on B12P12 nano-cage, the band gap decreases to 3.55 (3.53) eV. As can be seen in Fig. 3, the LUMO distribution of B12P12 nanocage is slightly changed upon adsorption of acetylene (ethylene) molecule. This small alteration
is consistent with negligible change in LUMO energy of acetylene- (ethylene-) B12P12 complex which is increased from −3.13 eV to −3.03 (−3.01) eV. The HOMO is further localized on P
atom with higher density at the interaction area. The energy of HOMO for acetylene- (ethylene-)
B12P12 complex is −6.58 (−6.54) eV, suggesting that increasing of energy of HOMO decreases the band gap.
For Ni atom, the energy of HOMO (LUMO) is −5.82 (−5.60) eV. Decoration of B12P12 nanocage by Ni atom results in significant changes in energies of the nano-cage. The band gap of the
B12P12 decreases upon adsorption of Ni atom, however, this reduction depends on the geometries of Ni-decorated B12P12 complex. A similar behavior was reported for Al12N12, B12N12, and Al12P12 [45-47]. The P2 geometry has the lowest band gap (2.60 eV), while P1 and P3 have largest band gap (2.68 eV). A closer look at the data reveals that the HOMO level is destabilized
(becomes higher in energy) in all geometries. The energies of HOMO are −5.70, −6.00, and
−5.59 for P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively, indicating a shift toward Ni atom’s HOMO
(−5.82 eV). On the other hand, the LUMO energies of B12P12 nano-cage slightly changed upon adsorption of Ni atoms. Except for P2 geometry, the LUMO is a little destabilized. The LUMO
energies for P1, P2, and P3 geometries are −3.02, −3.40, and −2.91 eV, respectively. The reason
of reduction in the band gap of Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage can be rationalized by the diffuse excess electrons generated by the interactions between phosphorous and the Ni atom. The
superficial d electrons of Ni atom which are loosely held with the nucleus and have high energy
become diffuse excess electrons, boosting the energy level of anew formed HOMO. The
localization of HOMO on Ni center is a convincing proof of this assertion. Considering the
shapes of HOMOs for different geometries of Ni-decorated B12P12 in Fig. 3, one can say that some electron densities are located on the nano-cage in all geometries as well as the density on
the Ni atom. One possible reason might be that more than one phosphorous atoms of the nano-
cage interact with Ni atom, creating extra electron density on Ni atom. Thereupon the excess
electrons donate back to the nano-cage. The LUMO has density spread over the entire skeleton
for P1 and P3 geometries; however, the electron density on the nano-cage in P1 is higher than P3
geometry which is consistent with more stabilization of its LUMO compared to P3 geometry.
For P2 geometry, the LUMO is mostly shifted to the metal center, while it has some electron
densities on the nano-cage.

Adsorption of acetylene or ethylene molecules on Ni-decorated B12P12 leads to an increase in the band gap. In the case of acetylene adsorption, the band gaps of Ni-B12P12 complexes are enlarged from 2.68 to 3.29 eV for P1, 2.60 to 3.30 eV for P2, and 2.68 to 3.30 eV for P3
geometry. Upon ethylene adsorption on Ni-B12P12 complex, the band gaps of P1, P2, and P3 geometries are increased from 2.68 to 316 eV, 2.60 to 3.36 eV, and 2.68 to 3.24 eV, respectively.
The change in the band gap is mainly attributed to the stabilization of HOMO. For acetylene, the
energies of HOMOs drop from −5.70 to −6.29 eV for P1, −6.00 to −6.30 for P2, and −5.59 to
−6.27 eV for P3 geometries. Furthermore, the energies of HOMOs reduces from −5.70 to −6.07
eV for P1, −6.00 to −6.22 for P2, and −5.59 to −6.20 eV for P3 geometries upon adsorption of
ethylene on Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage. Analysis of energy levels discloses that the energies of LUMOs are slightly affected. A small increase from −3.02 to −3.00 eV upon acetylene
adsorption and −3.02 to −2.91 eV upon ethylene adsorption on Ni-B12P12 complex is observed for P1 geometry. More so, for P3 geometry, a small decrease from −2.91 to −2.97 eV and −2.91
to 2.96 eV is found upon adsorption of acetylene and ethylene molecules on Ni-B12P12 complex, respectively. The changes in energy levels of LUMOs are more noticeable in P2 geometry where
the energies of LUMOs are increased from −3.40 to −3.00 and −3.40 to 2.86 eV after adsorption
of acetylene and ethylene molecules on Ni-B12P12 complex. As shown in Fig. 3, the densities on HOMOs in acetylene (ethylene)-Ni-B12P12 are not notably different from those in Ni-B12P12 complexes. More interestingly, the density of electrons on the nano-cage is increased compared

sections.heading: 3.4. Density of states
sections.text:
The alteration in electronic properties is an essential factor for evaluating the sensing capabilities
of the nano-cages. In order to gain a profounder understating of the changes in electronic
properties of pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage upon acetylene and ethylene adsorption, the DOS are also analyzed. To this end, the DOS of pristine and Ni-B12P12 are compared with their corresponding acetylene (ethylene) adsorbed complexes, as shown in Fig. 4. It is clear that
the DOS of pristine B12P12 nano-cage is slightly changed after complexation with acetylene or ethylene. Nonetheless, decoration of B12P12 nano-cage with Ni atom leads to a noticeable shift of the occupied orbitals toward high energy levels. These new HOMOs lie between HOMO and
LUMO of pristine B12P12 nano-cage. Interestingly, the intensities of peaks of HOMO are decreased for all geometries. The LUMO is slightly changed in all cases. Upon adsorption of
acetylene (ethylene) on Ni-B12P12 complexes, the DOS regress slightly toward pristine BP nanocage. Not only do the energy levels of HOMOs decrease, but also their peak intensities start
increasing. These results are in excellent agreement with our analysis on frontier molecular
orbitals.
It should be noted that the change in band gap brings about variations in conductivity. The
relationship between conductivity and energy band gap (Eg) can be expressed by following equation:
exp( / )gE kT   (7)
Here, is the electric conductivity and k denotes the Boltzmann constant. It is conspicuous that a
small decrease in the band gap results in significantly higher electrical conductivity. Based on
our findings, the pristine B12P12 nano-cage is not a suitable sensor for acetylene and ethylene adsorption because the change in band gap is only 0.15 eV for acetylene and 0.17 eV for
ethylene adsorption. On the contrary, Ni decoration of BP nano-cage boosts its sensing capability
toward aforementioned molecules. The highest change in band gap for acetylene-Ni-B12P12 complex is observed in P1 geometry (Eg = 0.41 eV). A stronger change in band gap (Eg = 0.54 eV) happens upon adsorption of ethylene on Ni-B12P12 complex in P1 geometry.
Fig. 4. DOS of different configurations of Ni-decorated B12P12 at P1, P2, and P3 configurations along with their complexes with acetylene (A) and ethylene (E) molecules.
3.5.Global indices of activities
In order to evaluate how the adsorption of Ni, acetylene, and ethylene affects the chemical
properties of B12P12 nano-cage, the global indices of activities are studied. The chemical potential (), hardness (), softness (S), and electrophilicity () of acetylene (ethylene)-Ni-
B12P12 complexes are listed in Table 3 and compared with pristine and Ni-B12P12 nano-cage. According to Koopmann theorem [56], the ionization potential (I) and electron affinity (A) are
directly associated to the energies of HOMO and LUMO, respectively. The ionization potential
of free B12P12 nano-cluster is very high (6.83 eV) which decreases to 6.58 (6.54) upon adsorption
of acetylene (ethylene) molecule. The decoration of the nano-cage with Ni further decreases the
ionization potentials to 5.70, 6.00, and 5.59 eV for P1, P2, and P3 geometries. The ionization
potentials start increasing again after complexation acetylene (ethylene) molecule with Ni-B12P12 nano-cage. The electron affinity of a free B12P12 nano-cluster is 3.13 eV. Except for P2 geometry, the electron affinities reduce slightly upon adsorption of acetylene (ethylene) molecule
or Ni atom on bare B12P12 nano-cage. The electron affinity increases to 3.40 eV after Ni decoration in P2 geometry. Acetylene (ethylene) adsorption on Ni-B12P12 complex causes further reduction in electron affinities for P1 and P2 geometries and an increase in electron affinity for
P3 geometry. The softness or hardness of a compound can be evaluated by their band gaps. The
larger the band gap is, the harder the compound is expected to be. The Ni-decorated B12P12 complexes are very soft because the band gap of pristine B12P12 decreases after adoption of Ni atom in different geometries. The softness values of P1, P2, and P3 geometries are 0.37, 0.38, 0.37 eV -1 , respectively. Since the band gaps increase again after complexation of acetylene or
ethylene molecules with Ni-B12P12 nano-cage, the softness decreases for these complexes. The electrophilicities of Ni-B12P12 complexes are higher than other complexes. The electrophilicity values of Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage are 7.09, 8.50, and 6.74 eV for P1, P2, and P3 geometries, respectively. In addition, the chemical potential of pristine B12P12 nano-cage increases after complexation with Ni atom or acetylene (ethylene) molecule.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
In summary, calculations based on DFT method have been performed to explore the
adsorption geometry, binding energy, NBO charge transfer, dipole moment, frontier molecular
orbitals, DOS, and global indices of activities of pure and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cages with acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption. Our results revealed that the interactions of these
small hydrocarbons with pure B12P12 nano-cage are very weak. The binding energies are −34.1 and −30.7 kJmole -1 for acetylene and ethylene adsorption, respectively. To enhance the
adsorption capacity of B12P12 nano-cage, the Ni-decorated B12P12 has been studied as the new adsorbent for acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption. Among the three possible geometries
for Ni decoration of B12P12 nano-cage (P1, P2, and P3), P1 is found as the most stable geometry. Their high adsorption energies show that Ni atom is chemisorbed on the surface of B12P12 in different geometries. Then, the adsorption property of acetylene and ethylene molecules on the
surface of Ni-decorated B12P12 with different geometries has been thoroughly investigated and the results were compared with those for pure B12P12 nano-cage. It was found that the binding energies of the former are significantly higher, suggesting that the adsorption capability of B12P12 nano-cage toward acetylene or ethylene molecules can be increased by Ni decoration. The P2 geometry (−270.6 kJmole -1 ) upon adoption of acetylene and P3 geometry (−232.0 kJmole -1 ) were
found more exothermic than other geometries. Moreover, the study of electronic structures
revealed that the band gaps of pristine B12P12 decrease upon decoration with Ni atom due to destabilization of HOMOs and increase again upon adsorption of acetylene or ethylene
molecules because of stabilization of HOMOs. The energy levels of LUMOs are almost
unaffected. On the basis of our theoretical findings, Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage can be considered as a superior media for acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption.

Highlights
The interactions of these small hydrocarbons with pure B12P12 nano-cage are very weak
Ni atom can be chemisorbed on the surface of B12P12 in different geometries
Adsorption capability of B12P12 nano-cage toward acetylene or ethylene molecules can be increased by Ni decoration
Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage can be considered as a superior media for acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, density functional theory (DFT) method with B3LYP-D and MPW1PW91 functionals is carried out to explicate the adsorption properties of small unsaturated hydrocarbons (acetylene and ethylene molecules) on the surfaces of pristine and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-clusters. More specifically, binding energies, natural bond orbital (NBO) charge transfer, dipole moment, frontier molecular orbitals, density of states (DOS), and global indices of activities are analyzed to deeply perceive the fluctuations of electronic and chemical properties of pure and Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-cage upon acetylene and ethylene adsorption. Our theoretical findings indicate that Ni atom can be adsorbed on the surface of B12P12 nanocage in three distinct configurations (P1, P2, and P3), where P1 is found as the most stable geometry. Although the acetylene (ethylene) molecule is weakly physisorbed on the surface of pristine B12P12 nano-cage with adsorption energy of −34.1 (−30.7) kJmole -1 , a significant improvement in their adsorption energies is found by utilizing Ni-decorated B12P12 as the adsorbent. The highest adsorption energy for acetylene (ethylene) adsorption on Ni-decorated B12P12 is −270.6 (−232.0) kJmole -1 in P2 (P3) geometry, suggesting that Ni decoration of B12P12 nano-cage enhances its capability toward acetylene and ethylene adsorption. It is also discovered the band gap of pristine B12P12 nano-cage decreases after complexation with Ni atom, and increases again upon adsorption of acetylene and ethylene molecules on its surface. In addition, the values of softness and electrophilicity for Ni-decorated B12P12 are higher than other structures. Our results suggest that Ni-decorated B12P12 nano-clusters show promise in acetylene and ethylene molecules adsorption.
